ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class was very well taught and interesting.
Learned about the basics of chemistry.
It helped me build my foundational knowledge in chemistry.
I learned a lot of chemistry
Very good understanding of general chemistry

I gained knowledge on solubility, electrochemistry, acid/base chemistry, nuclear chemistry, and other areas. We also learned various applications for each concept, in fields from biochemistry to environmental chemistry.
Apart from the concepts in the class, this course was the one that thought me the importance of a consistent schedule and maintaining it.
I learned a lot more about chemistry that I believe will help me with my further classes such as orgo and pchem!
reaction rates, acid base titrations, solving problems
I learned about reaction equilibria, reaction rates, and basic organic chemistry
Learned a lot of useful stuff for my future career.
Introduction to nuclear physics and thermodynamics
The usual Gen Chem II course material. In addition to that Professor Davis related general chemistry to her research and other fields that students are interested in, which was engaging.

Learned a lot about the concepts gen chem II covers like nuclear chemistry, radiation, acid/bases, and other things... last couple chapters of the chem text book if you are interested in looking. Just a continuation of gen chem i.

Got a great fundamental understanding of general chemistry concepts and also a nice introduction to organic chemistry concepts that I'm sure will serve me well next term. My quantitative reasoning improved, and I also picked up some good study habits for chem-specific problems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Davis consistently put so much time and effort into her students.

Strengths of the course are the professor. She is great, super nice and understanding of her students. Weakness of the course is that I would just not pay attention to a lot of the class because it was very similar to AP Chem from highschool.
The content per chapter seemed uneven a lot of times.

This course is the best chemistry course I have taken at Yale or any institution. Prof. Davis has really nailed down a wonderful teaching style that is constructive and allows for growth in her students.
There are four midterms, which makes it feel like you are constantly preparing for an exam. This made the course stressful.
Too much knowledge for one semester
Great class, best chem class i've taken at yale

Strengths: Caitlin! She is amazing. She is by far the best professor I have ever had for a Yale intro STEM course. I hated Gen Chem I, but she made me excited to learn in Gen Chem II. She is so understanding and accommodating, and it is so clear that she truly cares about our learning through her personality and all of her policies.
Weaknesses: The units feel a little disconnected from each other, especially towards the end. Nuclear chemistry was interesting, but I didn't love having it lumped in with the introductory organic chemistry at the end of the course.

I really enjoyed the separation of topics into smaller exams rather than one midterm and one huge final. I think sometimes the reading quizzes towards the end of the course did not line up with the reading itself.
The grading system seems nice at first until you realize you might have to take over 8 exams and write a paper if you're shooting for an A.
strengths: great professor, organized well, conducive to learning, organized in a way that rewards improvement
I thought it was a good course
The course was well taught, but it would be nice if the test had a longer format

Strengths: Professor Davis, the grading scheme, small class size.
Weaknesses: None

I think Prof Davis did a great job with this course. Some might say the retakes are weaknesses of the course as they end up taking away from the other midterms, but I think they are a strength because they emphasize the importance of studying properly the first time. Michael was also great in the class. The resources for this chem are, in my opinion, better than the first gen chem.

Strengths: clearly taught, extremely thoughtful, fair, and thorough professor, ample opportunities to FULLY learn the material, not just "get by." I loved the smaller "leminar" (lecture/seminar) class size, and it was so nice to have such an engaged professor who catered her teaching to her students' needs. I felt really seen and valued in this class which was so so nice and it definitely helped me actually learn what I needed to learn,. 
Weaknesses: Honestly none. This was a really great STEM class. I do wish it met twice a week for 1.25hr/lecture, as I think the material might be better covered over a longer lecture, but I know that this is the long standing structure of gen chem so no biggie.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you are interested in expanding your knowledge into chemistry or honestly any science. A basic foundation in chemistry is good. Also obviously if you are pre-med.
No. Not unless they need it for a pre-requisite.

I would recommend this course if Prof. Davis was the instructor. She takes her time to ensure that each of her students is aware of the opportunities available for success including Midterm Retakes and office hours. This was one of the best courses I have taken, and I finally feel like I have a grasp on chemistry!
if they have to take it, many do not choose to take this class.
Yes, Prof Davis is amazing and engaging and made chemistry interesting!

Since Yale intro STEM courses aren't exactly enjoyable even to those that are required to take them, I would say only to take 165 if you need it. However, if you do need it, absolutely take it with Professor Davis! She's great.
YES! but only if you have Caitlin Davis as your professor. she makes learning the material so much easier.

I would its a great chemistry course though I think theres more interesting classes. In other words, if it was a requirement for them I would say its not bad and theyll enjoy it. If it is not a requirement I wouldnt recommend it
If you have to take Chem 165, ABSOLUTELY take it with Prof. Davis. She is amazing!!
yes because you learn the foundations of chemistry that will be useful for those who want to pursue a career in the science field
if they have to take it for their major
Absolutely, Caitlin Davis is a fantastic teacher

Gen Chem II was a great experience. Being off-sequence had its perks. I liked the small class size and the grading scheme. The small class size allowed for more one-on-ones with the professor. The grading scheme promoted learning by assessing what you did wrong and a goal for improvement after every exam.

I think you have to take it, but if you can try to take it with Prof Davis and Michael. Together they are fantastic teachers who will meet with you and explain the problems and concepts very well. I probably got more out of this gen chem than the first one (not saying a lot, I don't remember a lot from the first gen chem).

Gen chem is gen chem  there are no bells and whistles  but Professor Davis is actually awesome. She renewed my faith in the idea that I belonged in STEM at Yale after some really rough semesters in large lectures but I so appreciated all the care she took to make sure we were learning. I feel like I have a great foundation going into organic chemistry and she made the class super fun. Pretty much everyone is in Gen Chem because they have to be for pre-med or another prereq, but taking it off-sequence with Professor Davis really is the way to go.
